content:
Hey @T-compiler! @Doc Jones and I had this idea for a rustc code reading club. I'm hoping that many of you would like to join for the first meeting! We had made a little website here.

The goal here is both to offer new contributors a friendly way to learn more about rustc but also to help those of us who already know rustc to learn more of it (I also think it's nice for people to see that even experienced compiler hackers get confused sometimes reading the code). To that end, I picked a bit of code to read for the first few meetings that I personally would like to know better -- the name resolution code (cc @Vadim Petrochenkov!). Would love to get suggestions for future meetings.

It occurs to me though, how would people feel about making this an "official" compiler team activity? We could make a little subteam (@Doc Jones and I would be happy to lead for now) and move the repo into rust-lang; we'd also create a t-compiler/code-reading-club stream. Both of us would definitely prefer it that way! I'll bring it up in the triage meeting today.
(It's also ok to run it a bit as an experiment and decide what to do later, though I don't personally see much harm either way.)
Under Links and Resources you will find a Google Calendar that contains the meetings details including the Zoom link that we will be using for the near future.

That sounds like something I'd be interested in. Do you think we could add the event to the compiler team calendar (maybe that would be part of making it a activity- Ah, there's already a calendar, perfect.
Yep-- although if it's part of the compiler team, it might make sense to move the event over to the main calendar
This is a wonderful idea. Thanks for working on this y'all!

Regarding moving this under rust-lang, I think that totally makes sense. The rustc-dev-guide is under rust-lang, the scope of work is under rust-lang, etc. So :thumbs_up: from me unless there's some reason y'all would rather keep it outside for now. :smile:
another thought: should this have its own zulip substream? t-compiler/reading-club? this was already in prev msg
Will this be recorded? I'll be on a plane when it happens.
@rylev no, no plans to record it, but it's a repeating event.
Recording both creates more work (somebody has to upload) and makes it a bit more intimidating for newcomers to participate, I think.

To that end, I picked a bit of code to read for the first few meetings that I personally would like to know better -- the name resolution code (cc @Vadim Petrochenkov!).

The date and time LGTM, I'll be able to participate most likely.
That reminds me -- cc @WG-rustc-dev-guide -- I am hoping that one outcome of this will be more contributions.

rylev said:

Will this be recorded? I'll be on a plane when it happens.

I was going to ask the same, I know we've talked in the Rust community about recording sessions and also know there are some conflicting things and I'm not sure what's the best solution :)
on one side keeping it private, intimate where people can feel comfortable would lead to not record things

on the other hand for people unable to attend, not having a great english level and wanting to re-watch the session even they attended (this happens to me very often), for people like members of the Rustc Dev Guide, to be able to watch it and come up with some stuff for the guide
so ... as I've said, there are conflicting things and I'm not sure if there's any solution
I guess one option may be to record it and leave it accessible to only the participants of the session + members of teams that before the meeting stated upfront they need access to it
so everyone would know who may watch it
unsure to be honest, just doing some kind of brain dump
cc @nikomatsakis @Doc Jones

I'm open to recording but (a) I don't want to do the work of uploading it to YouTube or whatever (I can share the access rights to download the file from zoom easily enough though) and (b) I'm just trying to respect those balanced priorities. If we have the ability to create "private" YouTube playlists or whatever, perhaps viewable only to members of the code reading club, that would be ideal.
(We could then add participants to the CRC via the team repo as normal)
It seems a bit overkill to have per-meeting permissions
I'd rather have it be "current and future members of the CRC"
all that said, I'm not sure how interesting it will be to watch :) but I guess we'll find out!

nikomatsakis said:

It seems a bit overkill to have per-meeting permissions

if this is the way of moving this forward I could handle per-meeting permissions
if people is ok with being more lax about it, even better for me :P
I could handle uploads to wherever if we decide to go this route

nikomatsakis said:

all that said, I'm not sure how interesting it will be to watch :) but I guess we'll find out!

yeah, agreed here too

I'm not in favor of recording. The original Code Reading Club doesn't record precisely because people, especially new people, aren't as self conscious about how others will perceive them based upon their knowledge level when there's no recording. I know this would limit my own participation.
:+1:

Would love to get suggestions for future meetings.

I have been working on a compiler for a university class and I hooked LLVM up to it as well as just printing assembly. It got me looking through the codegen code in rustc, I think this would be a great area for a Code Reading at some point.

Doc Jones said:

I'm not in favor of recording. The original Code Reading Club doesn't record precisely because people, especially new people, aren't as self conscious about how others will perceive them based upon their knowledge level when there's no recording. I know recording would limit my own participation.

Seems reasonable to me. I guess my request would be for really good note takers to participate :blush:
We could say that we're okay for people to do local recordings for their own later self-study?

I think this sounds wonderful! I'm wondering if it would help to provide some additional resources if people want to get some more context on a topic? For example, for the resolver, there is a chapter in the dev guide, and there is some higher-level chapters in the reference (names, along with some unmerged PRs).

I have a ton of notes on the resolver, and it was a bit intimidating to me without knowing some of the more general context.
This sounds really fun!

nikomatsakis said:

That reminds me -- cc WG-rustc-dev-guide -- I am hoping that one outcome of this will be more contributions.

:+1: :+1:

Eric Huss said:

I think this sounds wonderful! I'm wondering if it would help to provide some additional resources if people want to get some more context on a topic? For example, for the resolver, there is a chapter in the dev guide, and there is some higher-level chapters in the reference (names, along with some unmerged PRs).

We have the Dev Guide reference in the site's FAQs, but it is a good idea to add it to the Links and Resources section too, I think.
https://rust-code-reading-club.github.io/rustc/faq.html

Did you ever consider turning your notes into a blog post or posts? That might come in handy now. :)

I have a ton of notes on the resolver, and it was a bit intimidating to me without knowing some of the more general context.

Eric Huss said:

I think this sounds wonderful! I'm wondering if it would help to provide some additional resources if people want to get some more context on a topic? For example, for the resolver, there is a chapter in the dev guide, and there is some higher-level chapters in the reference (names, along with some unmerged PRs).

I have a ton of notes on the resolver, and it was a bit intimidating to me without knowing some of the more general context.

great idea
if you have a second, maybe add a comment here https://github.com/rust-code-reading-club/rustc/blob/main/src/meetings/2021-11-04.md ?
created #rustc-reading-club

Learning about the resolver sounds great! I'm looking forward to it :)

Would love to get suggestions for future meetings.

Here are a few suggestions, mostly things I'd like to understand better:

  • Type checking and WF checking (I've seen the term "WF checking" a lot, but I don't know much about what it involves)
  • Trait solving (both the current impl and Chalk)
  • Monomorphization, and how it interacts with codegen

@DevinR528's suggestion about codegen/LLVM also sounds interesting.

This is exactly what I am looking for. I want to dive into rustc and I have always felt like there aren't enough resources to grasp the subtleties of the Rust compiler, or at least an introduction into how to dive into it. Personally, I am looking for the rustc series (like the Rust Analyzer series by Aleksey Kladov). I think that would be really useful and valuable.
Also, I don't think I will always be able to attend, because of the timezone...
